content.description: One of the most high quality sport climbs in Arkansas! A top 5 route in the 5.12 range and probably best 5.12b! 3 really amazing sequences, sustained climbing, and beautiful rock! Not as visually enticing as Goldline, but after you work through the moves, you'll understand why this thing is world class!
content.location: Just left of Hudson Crack, and right of Fogell

content.description: Start on the small roof below the arête. Pull the hard start then climb the arête up to the flake that leads right and up to the horizontal break below the overhanging headwall. Traverse back left, clip the two permadraws, and fire the V1 dyno to the finishing jug and clip the anchors from there
content.location: Just left of Homey and right of The Clowning

content.description: Starts off on a bit of a blank slab and climbs into a flake feature. Work your way up to the last bolt and pull a small roof to get to the chains. Can get pretty wet and some of the holds have questionable rock quality.
content.location: Just left of EMP (right angling route) and about 40 feet left of Bucket Brigade.

content.description: Shares a start with the classic James Family All-Stars.  After the 2nd bolt start moving left onto a separate bolt line that ends with the shared anchors of Hudson Hangover.  The crux would have to be the lower section which is almost always wet and the holds aren't quite jugs.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor.  Shares anchor with Hudson Hangover
content.location: Shares start with James Family and shares end with Hudson Hangover.  Route is 2nd bolt line right of Hudson Crack.

content.description: Excellent dihedral start into an overhanging section with two fixed draws followed by a really enjoyable head wall and a fun little roof pull before hitting the chains. Very enjoyable varied route!
content.protection: 4 bolts, 1 fixed draws, plus anchors. Second and fourth hanger missing, you can use nuts and a cam to protect those areas.
content.location: First route in the area past the Hudson Crack/Supertang area. Look for a tall route with two fixed draws halfway up.

content.description: The first few moves are bouldery. A bolt is available to protect the start. One Second After is rated 5.9 in the Fixed Pin guidebook. I would say that after the beginning it backs off. Follow crack to fixed anchors.Can be started by traversing in from the right. This variation makes it around 5.7.
content.protection: One bolt, a few cams, and fixed anchors
content.location: Located at the end of the bucket brigade area. Its an obtuse right facing dihedral crack.

content.description:
Red river gorge esque route at Mt. Hudson. 

  Begin off a ledge and paddle your way up juggy incut crimps through some sequencing until you reach the base of a small roof. 

  Shake out and fire the small shouldery boulder problem over the lip and cruise those glorious jugs to the chains
content.location: Way Left of goldline, look for the RRG looking route. Obvious

content.description: Two starting bolts down from Hudson Crack, in the black streak. This shares starts with another 5.7, but goes straight up. Exceptionally fun plate pulling with fun movement. The bottom gets dirty and stays wet.
content.location: Black Streak 25 feet right of Hudson crack.

content.description: Traverse the ledge in to start if there is standing water. At the second bolt of Deercamp, veer off to the right towards a separate set of anchors. Quality holds and fun moves. Very underrated.
content.location: Shared Start with Deer camp, to the Right of Hudson Crack.

content.description:
Known to be the best crack in the state! 

  Obvious crack in the dihedral to the right of Supertang. 

  Fun, relaxed, easy climbing.
Starts vertical and heads into a slightly overhanging section before rolling up into slab under the roof. Fun climbing on mostly incut holds!
content.protection: 4 bolts plus anchors. I recommend hanging long draws on the anchors to lower from to minimalize rope drag.
content.location: Two routes left of PMA, two routes right of The Clowning. Ends up under the big roof in the middle of this section of wall.

content.description: Really fun moves up the flake feature into a really interesting sequence out and over the big roof!
content.location: Climbs the flake feature and big roof just left of Supertang.

content.description:
The King Line at Hudson! One of the best bolted 5.12's in Arkansas.   Superb moves on quality stone. 

  This route features almost all kinds of holds and all kinds of moves. Climbs like one large boulder problem.
content.location: Goldline is to the left of fogle, you can't miss it as it has a large gold streak running up the top half of the route.

content.description: Nice right angling, long, fun route. Mostly slab. Hopefully it's dry for you!
content.protection: 6 bolts plus anchors with rappel rings
content.location: Just to the right of Spanky Goes to Hollywood and two routes to the left of Bucket Brigade.

content.description: Climb the bolted arete and left facing dihedral (5.10a) to the chickenheaded slab. Plug gear and squeeze up and through the flaring roof crack (5.9).
content.protection: A few quickdraws for the first few bolts, a long sling for a chickenhead, hand sized pieces for the roof crack. Bolted anchors.
content.location: Left of PMA and right of Homie. This route actually climbs out the roof.

content.description:
Derives from the chanting banter from the film Batman (during the prison climbing scene) 

  Start the same for fogell but steer left through crimps making some tough moves, then to a small roof.
content.location: To the left of Fogell

content.description: An earlier and easier exit to Locomotive, Derailed pulls over the juggy lip to the left of Locomotive's roof. Climb the easy start to a largish ledge. A move off the ledge leads to flowy climbing on amazing holds and a short crux. Certainly worth doing if the full line is a little rich or you're short on time.
content.location: Start in the obvious wavy stone on the far left side of the impressive face. Head up 4(?) bolts and straight over the lip to a 2-bolt anchor with a single carabiner(03/2020). Maybe not the worst idea to unclip the anchor and lower off the last permadraw to reduce rope drag.

content.description: Consistently fun, with technical footwork that sets up for interesting moves. The base of the climb was very wet, but you can avoid the pool of water by starting on the left and walking the ledge to the first bolt. Gets a lot of sun and drys fast.
content.location: To the right of Hudson crack and Fogell. The first bolt is well above 12 feet off the ground. Scale the easy  ledge out to the right. When you get to the second bolt, the route splits off with another 5.10 and you will keep left to stay on Deer Camp.

content.description:
Always changing features on this route make for tons of variety. Technical beginning flake, fun jug haul mid section and slopers and a mini roof finish. Combined with the length of the route, it makes for a very fun warm up. However, only 2 stars because it can be rather condition dependent. 

  Caution: The haul from the fixed draw to the anchors is extremely dirty. You won't be able to see your top anchors from the last and only fixed draw until you begin to round out the roof. After rain, it was covered in moss and mud, making the final moves really sketchy. Likewise, the fixed draws are hanging directly on bolts without chain extensions and are prone to increased rope drag and a stuck rope when TRing.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 1 fixed draw and 2 fixed anchors with biners.
content.location: Left most climb at the crag. Starts on a nice orange face with an obvious flake.

content.description: Start off on this thin flake that runs halfway up the wall.  Work your way up the flake to a nice ledge and a 2nd flake greets you with solid gear placements and much better holds.  Get your last gear in here as you move out under the roof.  Clip the perma draw on the roof and make a final push over the roof and to the anchor on solid jugs.  The crux is the top section of the lower flake where it gets too small to get your hands in behind it.
content.protection: Standard rack. 1 perma draw and 2 bolt anchor with chains and rap rings.
content.location: This route is between the 2 classics The Clowning and Stand and Deliver. It starts on a beautiful flake just to the left of the arete that Stand and Deliver climbs.

content.description: Short moderate, with a few roofs containing large holds.
content.location: The first bolted route you see as you walk into the bluffline

content.description: Start as for Bucket Brigade, immediately move left on the slab. Execute a difficult sequence out the roof to chains
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts on the slab then a few permadraws.
content.location: The only route on the slabby face left of the first routes in Hudson (Bucket Brigade's chalked jugs mark the start)

content.description: Currently the third bolted route you come across when you enter. Hanging start off of some small boulders. Really enjoyable jug hauling on chicken heads for the first half, and then steep jug/ledge climbing to the chains. One of the best 5.10b's in Arkansas in my opinion.
content.protection: Glue in bolts and fixed draws on the anchors.

content.description:
There is something at Mt. Hudson for everyone, whether beginner or advanced. Come haul steep jugs on Bucket Brigade, get yer trad fix on Hudson Crack, or tech your way up the eye-catching features of Supertang. This area is full of classics and will provide good cragging time and time again.

 Also a popular area for hikers coming to visit Hudson Shelter. Please be courteous of others (leave the speaker in the car).
